entry.title: LLM Apps: Don't Get Stuck in an Infinite Loop! ðŸ’µðŸ’°
entry.summary:
What happens if an attacker calls an LLM tool or plugin recursively during an Indirect Prompt Injection? Could this be an issue and drive up costs, or DoS a system? I tried it with ChatGPT, and it indeed works and the Chatbot enters a loop! ðŸ˜Š
However, for ChatGPT users this isnâ€™t really a threat, because: Itâ€™s subscription based, so OpenAI would pay the bill. There seems to be a call limit of 10 times in a single conversation turn (I tried a few times).

entry.title: Kubernetes resource requests, resource limits, and LimitRanges
entry.summary: In this article, we explore the concepts of resource requests, resource limits, and limit ranges (LimitRanges) in Kubernetes. I will discuss how these concepts are used to manage resources, such as CPU, memory, and storage, in a Kubernetes cluster and provide examples that you can try in your test environment. Kubernetes resource requests, resource limits, and LimitRanges first appeared on 4sysops.

entry.summary: Go on a journey to explore the synergy between Identity and Access Management (IAM) and Infrastruture as Code (IaC).

entry.title: Move VirtualBox VM to other hosts
entry.summary: If you're running VirtualBox on multiple PCs, you may occasionally need to move virtual machines to another host. There are two methods for this task. First, you can copy the VM files to the new host and register them there. Alternatively, you can export the VM as an appliance and import it on the target PC. Move VirtualBox VM to other hosts first appeared on 4sysops.

entry.title: The September 2023 Security Update Review
entry.summary: Hello and welcome to another patch Tuesday in what continues to be a hot 0-day summer, with new exploits being identified by Apple, Cisco, and Microsoft. Take a break from your regularly scheduled activities and join us as we review the details of the latest advisories from Adobe, Microsoft, and more. If youâ€™d rather watch the video recap, you can check it out here. Apple Patches for September 2023 Apple kicked off the September patch release by patching two bugs in macOS Ventura, iPad and iOS, and watchOS to address active exploits. The first vulnerability is tracked as CVE-2023-41064 and represents a buffer overflow in Image I/O. The other bug, CVE-2023-41061, represents a validation issue that can be exploited used malicious attachments. According to Citizen Lab researchers, these bugs â€¦

entry.title: Join Azure Active Directory with Windows 11
entry.summary: Most companies' PCs are usually joined to Azure AD ("Entra ID") through a hybrid join, where the on-premises Active Directory (AD) is synchronized with Azure AD. However, if organizations have largely migrated their IT infrastructure to the cloud, PCs can directly join Azure AD. Like on-prem, there are several options for doing so. Join Azure Active Directory with Windows 11 first appeared on 4sysops.

entry.title: Manage enhanced security mode in Microsoft Edge using Group Policy
entry.summary: Enhanced security mode (ESM) introduced with Edge 111 is designed to protect the browser against attacks that manipulate data in the application's memory to inject executable code. ESM primarily aims to thwart attempts by malicious websites to exploit unresolved vulnerabilities in the browser. Manage enhanced security mode in Microsoft Edge using Group Policy first appeared on 4sysops.

entry.title: Network monitoring with the open-source tool Observium
entry.summary: Observium is a network monitoring tool based on Python and MySQL available for free as a Community Edition. It provides real-time information about detected devices, including their health and traffic through selected ports. Observium can utilize SNMP, WMI, or agents for monitoring devices. Network monitoring with the open-source tool Observium first appeared on 4sysops.

entry.title: Looking at the ChargePoint Home Flex Threat Landscape
entry.summary: We recently announced the rules and targets for the upcoming Pwn2Own Automotive competition. As we look forward to the event, we thought we would review the attack surface on some of the targets. We begin with the ChargePoint Home Flex â€“ a 240-volt Level 2 home charger that delivers up to 50 amps of power. The ChargePoint Home Flex is a level 2 electric vehicle charge station designed for use by end-users in their homes. The device has a minimal user interface in its hardware. The device employs mobile applications for both the installation and the regular operation of the equipment by the consumer. ChargePoint Home Flex Attack Surface Summary Broadly speaking, the attack surface of the device can be broken down into three categories. 1.Â Â Â Â ChargePoint Mobile Applications The ServicePro â€¦

entry.title: Kubernetes DaemonSets
entry.summary: A DaemonSet is a Kubernetes object that ensures that a copy of a Pod is always available on all (or selected) nodes in the cluster. The Pod can run background processes that provide services, such as logging, monitoring, networking, or usuage on every node in a Kubernetes cluster. Kubernetes DaemonSets first appeared on 4sysops.

entry.title: Static Pods in Kubernetes
entry.summary: In the last article of this Kubernetes tutorial, you learned how to encrypt Kubernetes Secrets at rest. In today's post, I will introduce you to Static Pods, a special type of Pod in Kubernetes that is not managed by the Kubernetes control plane. entry.title: Introducing Session Hijacking Visual Exploitation (SHVE): An Innovative Open-Source Tool for XSS Exploitation
entry.summary: Greetings, folks! Today, weâ€™re thrilled to introduce you to our latest tool: Session Hijacking Visual Exploitation, or SHVE. This open-source tool, now available on our GitHub, offers a novel way to hijack a victimâ€™s browser sessions, utilizing them as a visual proxy after hooking via an XSS or a malicious webpage. While some exploitation frameworks, such as BeEF, do provide hooking features, they donâ€™t allow remote visual interactions. SHVEâ€™s interaction with a victimâ€™s browser in the security context of the user relies on a comprehensive design incorporating multiple elements. These components, each fulfilling a specific function, form a complex, interconnected system that allows a precise and controlled session hijacking. Letâ€™s take a closer look at each of them: VictimServer: This compâ€¦

entry.title: Ansible yum module: Install RHEL/CentOS packages
entry.summary: The Ansible yum module manages packages using the yum package manager on CentOS and RPM-based Linux distributions, such as RHEL, CentOS, Fedora, and Rocky Linux. The Ansible yum module allows you to interact with the yum package manager and perform all basic package management tasks, such as installing, removing, and updating the packages. entry.title: Quickpost: PDF/ActiveMime Maldocs YARA Rule
entry.summary: Here is a YARA rule I developed to detect PDF/ActiveMime maldocs I wrote about in â€œQuickpost: Analysis of PDF/ActiveMime Polyglot Maldocsâ€œ. It looks for files that start with %PDF- (this header can be obfuscated) and contain string QWN0aXZlTWlt (string ActiveMim in BASE64), possibly obfuscated with whitespace characters. The regex used to detect characters QWN0aXZlTWlt interspersed [â€¦]

entry.title: Fix â€œThe WinRM client cannot process the requestâ€
entry.summary: If you work on Windows, one of the common errors you might encounter is when the WinRM client cannot process a request. Windows Remote Management (WinRM) is a Windows built-in remote management protocol that helps exchange information between different systems. For instance, you can spot it being used in Exchange, WSUS, and Microsoft Teams, especially when you're running PowerShell scripts and other third-party tools. Fix â€œThe WinRM client cannot process the requestâ€ first appeared on 4sysops.

entry.title: Encrypt Kubernetes Secrets at rest

entry.title: Juplink RX4-1500 Stack-based Buffer Overflow Vulnerability
entry.summary: EIP-b5185f25 A stack-based buffer overflow exists in JuplinkÂ RX4-1500, a WiFi router. An authenticated attacker can exploit this vulnerability to achieve code execution as root. Vulnerability Identifiers Exodus Intelligence:Â EIP-b5185f25 MITRE: CVE-2023-41028 Vulnerability Metrics CVSSv2 Vector:Â AV:A/AC:L/Au:S/C:C/I:C/A:C CVSSv2 Score: 7.7 Vendor References The affected product is end-of-life and no patches are available. Discovery Credit Exodus Intelligence Disclosure Timeline ... Read more Juplink RX4-1500 Stack-based Buffer Overflow Vulnerability The post Juplink RX4-1500 Stack-based Buffer Overflow Vulnerability appeared first on Exodus Intelligence.

entry.title: Ten sed command examples
entry.summary: Learn how to manipulate text in Linux using the powerful sed command. This post covers sed command examples of finding and replacing text based on text matching, case-insensitive operations and position, deleting lines based on position and pattern, appending text, writing to a new file, and printing specific lines. Ten sed command examples first appeared on 4sysops.

entry.title: CVE-2023-35150: Arbitrary Code Injection in XWiki.org XWiki
entry.summary: In this excerpt of a Trend Micro Vulnerability Research Service vulnerability report, Simon Humbert and Lucas Miller of the Trend Micro Research Team detail a recently patched remote code execution vulnerability in the XWiki free wiki software platform. This bug was originally discovered by Michael Hamann with public Proof-of-Concept (PoC) code provided by Manuel Leduc. Successful exploitation of this vulnerability would allow an authenticated attacker to perform an arbitrary code injection on affected systems. The following is a portion of their write-up covering CVE-2023-35150, with a few minimal modifications. A code injection vulnerability has been reported in the XWiki.Org XWiki. The vulnerability is due to improper input validation when rendering a link in the Invitation Application.â€¦

But this is inadequate for most networks, and can become a single point of failure for the centralized exchanges, [â€¦]

entry.title: How to a create a Kubernetes Secret
entry.summary: A Kubernetes Secret is a resource that is used to store sensitive information, such as passwords, authentication tokens, API keys, and TLS certificates, within a cluster. Storing such information in plain text is problematic, which is why a Secret can be used instead of Kubernetes ConfigMaps. How to a create a Kubernetes Secret first appeared on 4sysops.

entry.title: Dancing Offbit: The Story of a Single Character Typo that Broke a ChaCha-Based PRNG
entry.summary: Random number generators are the backbone of most cryptographic protocols, the crucial cornerstone upon which the security of all systems rely, yet they remain often overlooked. This blog post presents a real-world vulnerability discovered in the implementation of a Pseudo-Random Number Generator (PRNG) based on the ChaCha20 cipher. Discovery of a biased PRNG During a [â€¦]

These proofs are built upon decaf377 and poseidon377, which have been previously audited by NCC Group, with a corresponding public report. The review [â€¦]

entry.title: New features in Windows 11 23H2
entry.summary: The next Windows update, which Microsoft refers to as a big annual update, is Windows 11 23H2. It will offer numerous new features, which I will discuss in this article. Microsoft has not yet announced the release date; however, we expect to see it in September or October 2023. New features in Windows 11 23H2 first appeared on 4sysops.
